replies.commentBody: Do you know of any hard evidence that will stand  up in court  indicting the Logan act  was violated?

comments.commentBody:
Very fine reporting, folks. I can hear my Trump friends' protests, but given Trump's relations with Moscow, this report is expected. Hey, you Trump supporters mistrust Hillary Clinton, but your minds fail you with Trump's highly suspect relations with Russia.

Well, if you Trump people were "elitists" you would have studied Russian history.. We (you and I) are seeing another attempt at Russian expansion in the world. And with Trump, they have their boy. Ronald Reagan is rolling in his grave (Google "Ronald Reagan").

The very bad news for us is that the Trump administration is opaque (Googlei it) with respect to Russia. The release of information from the Obama administration merely gives us information on Russia's activities.

Republicans nominated the wrong person in the Republican primaries. Now, McConnell and Ryan have to deal with him to get their agendas through.

But right, it's whatever the Trump supporters in those swing states want. If we support Russia in its effort to gain power in the world, then American democracy will yield to Russian totolitarianism. Ronald Reagan is rolling in his grave.

It's curious to me that Trump parts with the strategies of all presidents before him in Russian relations. He denies business interests there, but reality indicates otherwise.

Congress has no ethical stance to impeach.

All the more reason for the insistance that Trump release his tax returns!  Where there is smoke, there's bound to be fire.  The American public needs to know.  By refusing to divest himself from his businesses and not releasing his tax returns, along with his Russian connections, he leaves us no way to trust him.  How can we work with and support such a president?!  Republican Congressmen and Senators that agree to go along with him without demanding to see his tax returns and demand he recuse himself from his business interests may be committing acts of  treason.  They need to demand  he prove where his interests lie.

replies.commentBody: Not going to happen. https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/house-intelligence-chairman-den...

comments.commentBody: Kudos to the Gray Lady for keeping this in the news. This is deadly serious and needs to be investigated further; unfortunately we must depend on the so-far-absent courage, backbone and integrity of the Trump Party in Congress. They are no longer Republicans.

replies.commentBody: There's been some social media rumbling to the effect that all the five former presidents should write an op ed, together, for the Times.  Now THAT would be bipartisan and independent.

comments.commentBody: All government officials that allowed this to happen must make sure the whole truth and all the details come to light--that means you too Pres. Obama. I don't care if you are no longer in government--following thought, doing whatever you have to to make sure that we know everything--you owe that to the American People. Lets get going... this is taking way too long!

The American people and Congress need to see Trump's tax returns.  These documents will either confirm or refute the claims that Trump and high officials in his administration had contact with Russian officials, and the reasons, if any, for them to have occurred.  There needs to be an independent investigation into this matter to ascertain once and for all whether this president did anything unlawful or in contravention of the Constitution.  The American people have a right to know, as President Nixon said, whether their president is a crook.
Who are you gonna believe... the president of the US of A, or the facts?  Imagine this conundrum?

replies.commentBody: It seems they were collecting intelligence as fast as it was being generated. Doesnt seem a question of their diligence--story was unfolding minute-to-minute.
The FBI was too focused on Clinton's emails -- so was the NYT.

comments.commentBody: Just what we were looking for on a day in which President Trump and his team have been resting on their laurels, after the address to the Congress yesterday. I think it is becoming clearer by the day that Obama administration officials are behind the leaks. And if the evidence mentioned here is strong, there is no getting away for the Trump team from facing some harsh consequences. We hope the investigation would lead to President Trump's treasure trove in Russia. One only wishes the Obama administration and intelligence agencies were diligent enough to unearth the conspiracy last year. Then there would be no room for a cover-up and perhaps Trump wouldn't be President now.

I will miss this ethical man in the White House.

Obama could have sounded a very public alert potentially altering the election, but instead he took these wise steps so others could investigate and reveal the truth - whatever it might be.

replies.commentBody:
The putting up is supposed to be done within the context
of a complete investigation by the Senate and House
Intelligence Committees. I would not put
great faith in the House's investigation since I am
confident that will degenerate into partisan warfare
rather quickly. It will then fall to the Senate committee
to do a thorough investigation and issue a detailed report
without descending into the same type of open
(and surely staged for purposes of stalling, discrediting, waffling etc.) warfare in the House.

In the meantime there will be lots of media reports that
come from who knows where and with many a secret agenda. The
ensuing fog is designed to exasperate and render apathetic
the typical low info citizen who can then be expected
to express impatience with the length of time that is
being taken etc etc. How that subsequently plays out will be very
interesting to follow.
Did you read the article? Because he wanted the facts to be known, he's "behind it"?

That's exactly why an independent special prosecutor is needed.
Journalists can get stories from various sources , but don't have subpoena power like trained lawyers have.
If there were any series of events that cries for an independent investigation, its this.
The Trump admin. and GOP should welcome it - if we get all the evidence out, put it before the American people and other lawmakers, and if the evidence says this is indeed much ado about nothing, then Trump is finally cleared of any Putin taint.

But if there is evidence of ties between Russia and the Trump admin/ GOP leadership, then they must face the facts and be tried to the fullest extent possible.

The future of American democracy could be at stake.

comments.commentBody: So Trump was right after all to say that Obama was behind all the unsupported conspiracy theories about Russian and Trump fixing the election. It hard to imagine that the investigations of the  FBI and CIA and multiple other intelligence agencies have found nothing incriminating  to date without also concluding that there is likely nothing there to find. Now the NYT issues another "breaking news" report that is again filled with anonymous sources leaking  unverifiable information and offering no evidence of any kind. This is becoming tedious and it's time to either put up or shut up.

Perfect timing for the release of this story.  Empty-headed pundits were reacting with heaving chests all day about the new and improved Trump on display last night:  this story is the new narrative--Trump is a fraud--always has been, always will be.  The GOP can only win by cheating.  Trump should soon be packing.  All of his executive actions should be nullified and Garland should be confirmed as a justice on the Supreme Court.  Grosuch's nomination was made possible through the GOP's theft of the seat that rightfully belongs to the man who was nominated by President Obama.

If there had been secret meetings between Obama associates and the Russians in 2008, Fox and the Wall Street Journal would have reported on it in detail every days for years and every Republican Congressional committee would have launched an investigation.

replies.commentBody: It does, but don't bet a dime that this GOP will get to the bottom since they refuse to seriously dig.

comments.commentBody: It's called "news" folks. It's early to show all their cards. No instant gratification. But this feels like the tip of a very large, cold, point iceberg.

replies.commentBody: Civilians are forbidden by law to enter negotiations with foreign powers. And arguing that a foreign power's meddling in an American free election, our most precious birthright, is no big deal, is despicable. Treasonous, actually.
Why did they want him to be president so badly? You're not curious about that? You think it was in our interest or Putin's?

I was hoping nobody would mention the Logan Act. Oh, well .... Nobody ever got convicted under Logan, only one person got indicted, and nobody got prosecuted. The act is more than 200 years old, and it is empty: it has no force, because if challenged it would get overturned on the basis of the First Amendment. Look it up.

Nobody got convicted because Logan is empty: a private citizen walks into Putin's office and says I am here to negotiate on behalf of ... who exactly? Obama? Putin calls Obama: did you send this joker? No, ok. Putin throws the private citizen out of the Kremlin.

The private citizen says, I am here "negotiating" on behalf of Trump. Putin: that's nice, but Trump is not president. PC: Yeah, but he might be. Putin: Well, I like that, and when he is, give me a call. In the meantime the only person doing foreign policy is Obama. So please get out of my office.

By definition, nobody can negotiate foreign policy except the well known members of the US government. Without them, there is no negotiation.

Now, impersonating Obama, or Kerry – that’s a different matter. Though not that easy to do.

comments.commentBody:
Let's say elect Trump sent Mike Flynn to tell some Russians to tell Putin: Don't worry, when I am sworn in the sanctions are off.

What exactly is wrong with that? How is it illegal?

Let's say Trump sent Mike Flynn or somebody else to tell some Russians to tell Putin: Don't worry, when and if I am elected president, the sanctions are off.

What exactly is wrong with that? How is it illegal?

Let's say Trump sent somebody to say to the Russians, maybe you ought to hack the DNC.

What exactly is wrong with that? How is it illegal?

By the way, the sanctions are not off.

And, by the way, Podesta, Brazile, Wasserman-Schultz and others have not denied the content of their emails.

Did all of that help Trump win? Maybe, doubt it but maybe. So? "Meddling" is not illegal. And inviting to "meddle" is also not illegal.

replies.commentBody: Sadly, all indications are that most Republican officials and Trump supporters already do support him -- no matter what. They don't let facts get in the way of their own agendas.

comments.commentBody: So where is all the information now?  When you add all this up;  the notion of manipulating the election, contact between Trumps people and the Russian, Trumps reluctance to release his tax records, his numerous bankruptcy business failures, his conflict of interest as president and controlling his business interest it is clear something is wrong here.  The bigger question is will all these Republicans support this chaotic, unpredictable guy that under mysterious circumstances is now the President, let's hope not.

At this point too many people in the government know and have seen the raw intelligence for sham congressional committees to let this slide by.  With time only a special prosecutor will be seen as legitimate.
Drip, drip, drip.

replies.commentBody:
"I fear this will only strengthen the idea held by Trump and his supporters of a "partisan witch-hunt.""

So what? The Trumpsters are going to resist full disclosure any way they can, and will characterize any diligence as a conspiracy to unfairly besmirch him. No matter. The digging must go on, and the fact that relevant information has been widely distributed is a hopeful sign that the truth will eventually surface.
Great  comment and the launch of "Russo-Trumpian"
Perhaps not well written, but I agree after reading the article and at least some of the letters. Please get over it folks, Trump is president.

comments.commentBody: While every new piece of information about Russian electoral meddling and Russo-Trumpian collusion that gradually reveals itself to the public is absolutely jarring (to an extent where most feel the need to describe themselves first and foremost as people who don't normally subscribe to conspiracy theories), I fear this will only strengthen the idea held by Trump and his supporters of a "partisan witch-hunt." To me, this signifies a stark and glaring concern and astonishment on behalf of the intelligence officials uncovering the ever-growing interference and connections between Russia and Trump's administration. It seems natural to fear that the incoming administration, one that had already repeatedly shown a denial and/or complete dismissal of information and facts that didn't align with their reality and their prerogatives, would seek to plug up and retain the information that was utterly damming. The information was terrifying in that it signified a potentially dark and sinister manipulation of the U.S. political system that could be used as a basic structure for further unprecedented meddling in Western elections. Yet, despite this, facts and events that have seemed clear and apparent to myself and others, are antithetically viewed by those surrounding and supporting Trump. What to me shows further evidence of the severity of Russian interference, will most likely be viewed as partisan, fake news, as Trump has deeply politicized the intelligence agencies and their work.

For what it's worth, unlikely Hansel and Gretel have an real interest in following the crumbs. They are beholden entirely unto themselves and no other, including the American republic, or what will be left of it before this feckless administration and Congress is done.

For a lot of people this is moving too slowly.  Such people question, why Obama did not stop it before the elections?  What was the FBI leadership upto in upstaging Obama and throwing the election for Trump?  Yesterday may have been the last best day for Trump, before he is thrown out.  The wheels of Justice have to move faster in this IT enabled super fast world, otherwise people will get bored.
So right to his final days, uber smart Obama was working for us.  Meanwhile the ego in chief was tweeting and golfing.

replies.commentBody: All I had to see was "a large majority of Americans agree with President Trump" in your post to recognize it as more Trumpist horse manure.

And all of Trump's comments are accurate?

The point is, Are any accurate? Yes, a few.

43 Million unemployed? A clear and deliberate LIE.

Nope.  A large majority of Americans do not agree with the serial liar Gropenfuhrer on ANYthing.  Actual summary: there is real evidence of Russian interference and of collusion between Trump administration and Russian intelligence; lots of people in a position to know and evaluate the information knew about it, feared it would be covered up (strong evidence for that from the campaign) and distributed it in different ways to try to preserve it.   The sources (since like most Trumpanzees you don't understand journalism OR the truth at ALL) are in fact legitimate and credible (Baquet or the reporters know exactly who they are) , or the Times wouldn't run the story.  Sorry to bust your pathetic bubble. You would have defended Nixon to the end too, I'm sure.  You'll see.  It will all come out.

comments.commentBody:
A more tortured, deceptive and vacuous attempt at "news" or legitimate journalism, we've seldom seen.

Summary of this "story": Unidentified Obama Admin staffers, angry about the Trump & GOP electoral victory that Obama-Clinton-DNC & Press arrogantly assumed would not happen, engaged in an aggressive and malicious campaign of leaking confidential information, spreading anti-Trump rumors & distributing dubious materials alleging illicit contact and election tampering by unidentified Russians, whom no one can confirm were actually Russians or members of any government agency, and unidentified Trump associates, whom no one can identify or prove actually worked with or communicated with Trump or his campaign.

Despite the lack of legitimate or credible sources, facts, evidence or proof, readers are supposed to believe that Obama & Hillary Clinton lost the election, not because Americans wanted change and found the corrupt career politician, Hillary Clinton, to be an untrustworthy serial liar and highly undesirable as president, but because Russia did it.

Given the foregoing, it's easy to understand why a large majority of Americans agree with President Trump's conclusion that the New York Times, and others like them, are harming the American people by generating "fake news". We deserve a truly free & independent press, rather than the divisive left-wing propaganda machine we're being subjected to.

replies.commentBody: Harry Reid did that, but the NYT cut it from the article and went with Comey, who seems to have lied (or been duped). I say give it to the WaPo, like last time.

comments.commentBody: I take heart in the lessons of our past:  If crimes were committed at the highest levels of our government and our government is lying about it, a brave and patriotic American will make sure that all the evidence is delivered to The New York Times.

replies.commentBody: Easy one:  he is poisoning the well so that when one of the national newspapers who still have Woodward/Bernstein quality journalists unearths the new Pentagon Papers, at least 63,355,306 citizens won't believe them.  He's covering his tracks.

comments.commentBody: I wonder why Trump has been so anxious to label the NYT as fake news and that the "liberal" press is the enemy of the people?

replies.commentBody: The Republican party and alt right are not one and  the same.

comments.commentBody: The bigger story is how the Republican party and Alt Right have continuously chipped away at and all but eviscerated the voting rights act including the accelerated gerrymandering in so many districts which disenfranchised millions of voters.  If there's any concern about Russia it should be on the big oil deals that Trump intends to make -- to exploit the Arctic and to destroy the environment -- that is his quintessential dream and all of our collective nightmare.  @johannaclear

replies.commentBody: Leftists. We won. You lost.

It's so very sad, that there are 63,355,306 people in this country who voted for a xenophobic, homophobic, misogynistic, racist bully who mocked a disabled person on national television and then made up a ridiculous story to avoid taking responsibility.
We all lost.  Some Americans are just not able to admit this fact to themselves apparently.

comments.commentBody: The fact that 38% of Americans still support Trump is a damning indictment of the basic competence of the American voter.
